Fig. 1 XRD diffractograms of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites, with x ranging from 0 to 0.5 (♦ BaCO3 and ● BaCoO2.95). The XRD diffractogram of La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 variant is also included as reference. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Enlargement of the specific zone from 31 to 35° 2θ of Fig. 1, for LaCoO3, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3 and La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 perovskites (● BaCoO2.95). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 H2–TPR profiles of La1-xBaxCoO3 samples with x ranging from 0 to 0.5. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 O2–TPD profiles of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites, with x ranging from 0 to 0.5. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Evolution of: α, β and total desorbed oxygen species with lanthanum substitution degree for La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites. The corresponding values to La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 are represented with hollow symbols. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CO2–TPD profiles normalized according to sample mass for LaCoO3, La0.3Ba0.7CoO3 and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 samples. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NO-to-NO2 oxidation capacity of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites with x ranging from 0 to 0.5, together with La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite as reference. Feed: 500 ppm NO, 6% O2 and Ar to balance; W/Q = 200 (g h mol−1). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 NO, NO2, NOx (NO + NO2), NH3 and N2O outlet concentration during two consecutive lean-rich cycles in stationary state of: LaCoO3, La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 and La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskites at 350 °C. Feed: 500 ppm NO, 6% O2/3% H2 and Ar to balance; W/Q = 200 (g h mol−1). Graphical abstract Perovskites (ABO3) have emerged in recent years as an economic alternative to noble metals for oxidation-reduction reactions in diesel engines aftertreatment systems. Sr-doped La1-xSrxCoO3 perovskites have shown high efficiency in NO oxidation and limited NOx reduction efficiency. Alternatively, in this work, the effects of barium doping on NOx removal efficiency of LaCoO3 perovskite are explored with the aim of developing a more promising perovskite base catalyst. Bulk perovskites were prepared by substituting La3+ with increasing Ba2+ doping levels, i.e. La0.9Ba0.1CoO3, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3, La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 and La0.5Ba0.5CoO3. The prepared catalysts were characterized in terms of crystalline structures identification (XRD), specific surface area (N2 adsorption-desorption at -196 °C), reducibility and oxidation state of Co ions (H2-TPR), concentration and strength of adsorbed oxygen species (O2-TPD) and surface basicity (CO2-TPD). The characterization results suggest that charge imbalance associated to Ba2+ accommodation in the perovskite lattice in substitution of La3+ leads to a preferential formation of oxygen vacancies. As a result, Ba-doped perovskites improve NO-to-NO2 conversion with respect to LaCoO3 perovskite. La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskite shows the best NO oxidation efficiency (66 % at 350 °C). This fact is associated to the higher oxygen vacancies concentration, which favors the exchange capacity between oxygen in the lattice and in the gas phase. This sample also shows the best NOx storage and reduction efficiency (maximum NOx-to-N2 reduction of 40 % at 350 °C). On the one hand, NOx adsorption is promoted due to the best balance between NO oxidation capacity and NOx adsorption sites accessibility. On the other hand, the higher strength of NOx adsorption sites promotes a slower nitrates decomposition, which favors NOx reduction during rich period. The obtained results improve the NOx removal efficiency of reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 sample (maximum NOx-to-N2 reduction of 10 % at 350 °C). Thus, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 catalyst is considered as a more promising base material for automotive applications. Keywords NOx removal NO oxidation NOx storage and reduction Pt-free catalyst LaCoO3 perovskite 1 Introduction Considering better fuel efficiency and lower CO2 emissions, diesel engines have attracted more attention than stoichiometric gasoline engines. However, the NOx emissions control of diesel exhaust gases is still a technological challenge due to the operation with a net oxidizing environment [1]. In order to meet the current (EURO VI in Europe) and upcoming Emission Standard Legislation, additional catalytic strategies are mandatory to be implemented, such as NOx Storage and Reduction (NSR) [2] or Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) [3]. NSR technology operates cyclically between oxidizing-reducing conditions using 1.5 % Pt–15 % BaO/Al2O3 as model catalyst. During oxidizing conditions (lean period), NO2 adsorption is more effective than NO adsorption [2]. Thus, the oxidation of NO-to-NO2 is considered a primary step to promote NOx storage via nitrites or nitrates [4] formed over an alkali or alkali-earth material (i.e. BaO). Then, the environment switches to reducing conditions (rich period) via injection of a reductant such as H2, CO or HC. As a consequence, the stored nitrates are released and reduced over the platinum sites. In order to achieve higher NOx removal efficiency, NSR model catalyst requires around 1–2 % of Pt to maximize NO-to-NO2 conversion during lean period. However, this compound suffers from issues such as high cost and poor thermal stability under highly oxidative conditions [5]. Perovskites have attracted attention in recent years as potential alternative to save the limited noble metal resources and decrease the catalyst cost in automotive application [6]. Perovskites oxides have the general formula of ABO3, where A corresponds to a rare-earth or alkaline earth cation and B to a transition metal cation. Interestingly, a great range of perovskites oxides can be obtained by the partial substitution of A and B cations. We recently reported that the partial substitution of lanthanum by strontium in LaCoO3 perovskites improved NO-to-NO2 oxidation activity beyond that of the model Pt-based catalyst formulation [7]. This also leads to a promotion of the NOx removal efficiency [8]. Among La1-xSrxCoO3 (with x = 0−0.5) perovskites, the La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 formulation showed the best NO-to-NO2 oxidation activity and NOx storage and reduction performance. Alternatively, other studies analyzed the potential benefits of the La3+ partial substitution by other cations, such as Ca2+, Ba2+, Mg2+, K+ or Ce4+, in different perovskite compositions [9–14]. Note that Ba2+, Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions present the same oxidation state than Sr2+. Among them, BaO has demonstrated the best balance between high basicity and homogenous dispersion in the model NSR formulations [2,15]. As a result, BaO is widely accepted as an efficient NOx adsorption site in NSR system. Indeed Hodjati et al. [16] observed that the NOx storage performance was in the order of Ca < Sr < Ba on alternative non-substituted perovskites (with A = Ca, Sr or Ba; and B = Sn, Zr or Ti). Based on these results, we assume that the partial substitution of La3+ by Ba2+ could be a promising alternative to promote the NOx storage and reduction efficiency of LaCoO3 perovskites, which to our knowledge has not been yet reported in the literature. Hence, the first objective of the present study was to determine the Ba doping level that maximizes NO-to-NO2 oxidation and NOx removal efficiencies. In order to accomplish this objective, a series of Ba-doped La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites were prepared by citric acid method. The prepared samples were deeply characterized and tested for NO oxidation reaction (NO-to-NO2 conversion), as well as for NOx storage and reduction process (NOx-to-N2 efficiency). Consequently, relevant information on the key factors for the NO-to-NO2 oxidation and the capacity to store, release, and reduce NOx in La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites is extracted. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, Sr-doped and Ba-doped LaCoO3 perovskites for the NOx storage and reduction in automobile applications has not been compared yet. Therefore, the second objective of this study was to define the most promising base material for automotive applications between Sr- and Ba-doped perovskites. In this way, the physico-chemical properties and NSR performance of the La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites were compared with the optimum bulk perovskite (La0.7Sr0.3CoO3) set in our previous work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Perovskite catalyst preparation Bulk La1-xBaxCoO3 catalysts were prepared using the optimal synthesis conditions already reported by our group [7]. In brief, appropriate amounts of La(NO3)3·6H2O (Fluka), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich) and Ba(NO3)2 (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) were dissolved in distillated water under vigorous stirring. Then, citric acid (C6H8O7·H2O, CA) was added as a complexing agent and organic loading for the combustion process with a citrate to nitrates (CA/N) molar ratios of 1.1, whereas the pH value was adjusted to 8 by ammonia aqueous solution (25 % as NH3, Panreac). After solvent evaporation at 80 °C, the gel was further dried at 120 °C overnight and then calcined in 5% O2/He (60 mL min−1) at 650 °C for 4 h. The following samples, listed from low to high Ba substitutions of La, were synthesized: LaCoO3, La0.9Ba0.1CoO3, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3, La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 and La0.5Ba0.5CoO3, together with the La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite as reference. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Philips PW1710 difractometer. The samples were finely ground and were subjected to Cu Kα radiation in a continuous scan mode from 5° to 70° 2θ with 0.02° per second sampling interval. PANalytical X`pert HighScore specific software was used for data treatment. Textural properties of the samples were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption at - 196 °C using Micromeritics TriStar equipment. The reducibility of the samples was investigated by Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) using Micromeritics AutoChem II equipment. The quartz tube reactor was loaded with 0.1 g of sample and pretreated with 30 mL min−1 of 5% O2/He mixture at 600 °C for 30 min, and then cooled down to 50 °C. Afterwards, samples were heated from room temperature to 950 °C with 10 °C min−1 heating rate in a 5% H2/Ar gas mixture with 30 mL min−1 flowrate. Water generated during sample reduction was removed using a cold trap before gas analysis by TCD. The strength and concentration of different oxygen species was investigated by Oxygen Temperature Programmed Desorption (O2-TPD) using Micromeritics AutoChem II equipment coupled to a MKS Cirrus LM99 mass spectrometer. The sample (0.1 g) was introduced in a quartz tube reactor and pretreated with 50 mL min−1 of 5% O2/He mixture at 600 °C for 5 min and then cooled down to 40 °C. Afterwards, samples were heated from room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 50 mL min−1 of Helium gas flow. The surface basicity of the samples was investigated by CO2 Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD) using the Micromeritics AutoChem II equipment coupled to a MKS Cirrus LM99 mass spectrometer. The quartz tube reactor was loaded with 0.1 g of sample and pretreated in 50 mL min−1 of 5% O2/He mixture at 550 °C for 30 min and then cooled down to 35 °C in a flow of He. The adsorption of CO2 was performed in a flow of 5% CO2/He (50 mL min−1) for 60 min. Then, samples were heated from room temperature to 900 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1 in He (50 mL min−1). The CO2 desorption was continuously monitored with a mass spectrometer following the CO2 signal 150 (m/e = 44). 2.3 Catalytic activity In order to guaranteed the absence of external and internal mass transfer limitations [7]. The catalytic tests were carried out in a vertical stainless steel reactor filled with 0.5 g of 0.3−0.5 mm pelletized catalyst, and placed inside a 3-zone tube furnace. Gases were feed via mass flow controllers and the temperature was measured by a thermocouple inside the catalyst bed. The total flow rate was set at 2000 mL min−1, whereas the packed bed density of the samples is around 1.4 g mL−1. Thus, the Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) was 340,000 h-1, which corresponds to 240,000 mL (g h)-1 Weight Hourly Space Velocity (WHSV). The outlet gas composition was continuously measured using a MKS MultiGas 2030 FT-IR analyzer linked to a MKS Cirrus quadrupole MS. NO, NO2, NH3, N2O, and H2O were quantitatively monitored by the FT-IR analyzer, whereas H2, N2, and O2 were qualitatively monitored by the MS analyzer. 2.3.1 NO-to-NO2 oxidation experiments The feed composition in NO oxidation test was 500 ppm of NO, 6% O2 and Ar as balance gas. The conversion of NO-to-NO2 was calculated after steady state at even temperature was reached, which usually needed around 20 min after temperature stabilization, according to Eq. (1): (1) X NO-to-N O 2 ( % ) = F NO in − F NO out F NO in × 100 2.3.2 NOx storage and reduction (NSR) experiments The feed composition was varied in the consecutive lean-rich periods. During the lean period (150 s), the feed composition was: 500 ppm NO, 6% O2 and Ar as the carrier gas. During the rich period (20 s), oxygen was replaced by hydrogen with a concentration of 3%. The catalytic activity was evaluated in terms of the parameters listed below. 2.3.2.1 NOx storage capacity (NSC). Percentage amount of NOx stored during the lean period related to the amount of NO at the inlet (Eq. 2), (2) N S C ( % ) = F NO in t L − ∫ 0 t L F NOx out d t F NO in t L × 100 F NOx out is the NOx molar flow (μmol min−1) at the outlet and t L (min) is the length of the lean cycle. 2.3.2.2 NOx global conversion ( X N O ). Amount of NO converted during the whole operation (lean and rich cycles) with respect to the total amount of NO fed to the reactor (Eq. 3), (3) X NOx ( % ) = F NO in ( t L + t R ) − ∫ 0 t L + t R F NOx out d t F NO in ( t L + t R ) × 100 where t R (min) is the length of the rich cycle. 2.3.2.3 Yield of N-compounds ( Y NO 2 , Y NH 3 , Y N 2 O and Y N 2 ). Mol percentage of the corresponding component at the outlet related to NO amount at the inlet, i.e. (4) Y N O 2 ( % ) = ∫ 0 t L + t R F NO 2 out d t F NO in ( t L + t R ) × 100 (5) Y N H 3 ( % ) = ∫ 0 t L + t R F NH 3 out d t F NO in ( t L + t R ) × 100 (6) Y N 2 O ( % ) = ∫ 0 t L + t R 2 F N 2 O out d t F NO in ( t L + t R ) × 100 (7) Y N 2 ( % ) = ∫ 0 t L + t R 2 F N 2 out d t F NO in ( t L + t R ) × 100 where F NO 2 out , F NH 3 out , F N 2 O out and F N 2 out are the molar flows (μmol min−1) at the outlet of NO2, NH3, N2O and N2, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the prepared La1-xBaxCoO3 catalysts. La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 variant is also included as reference. As can be observed, pure perovskite diffraction patterns were observed for LaCoO3 and La0.9Ba0.1CoO3 samples. The absence of additional phases for La0.9Ba0.1CoO3 variant suggests that Ba2+ was partially accommodated inside the lattice. However, phase segregations in form of BaCoO2.95 and BaCO3 are identified for lanthanum substitutions above 10 %. In contrast, no phase segregations are observed in Fig. 1 for La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite. Indeed, the presence of impurities in form of SrCO3 was only evident for higher Sr doping degrees in our previous work [7]. Thus, LaCoO3 perovskite seems to accept a higher La3+ substitution degree by Sr2+ than by Ba2+, without destabilizing the perovskite structure [17]. This behaviour can be as a consequence of the differences in basicity and ionic radius of both compounds. On the one hand, the higher basicity of Ba favours the reaction between the Ba2+ and CO2 released from the decomposition of citric acid during the calcination step. This leads to the formation of BaCO3 due to the carbonation of segregated barium oxides [18]. On the other hand, the ionic radius of La3+ (1.15 Å) is closer to that of Sr2+ (1.13 Å) than that of Ba2+ (1.35 Å). This leads to a decrease of structural stability of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites favoring the formation of BaCoO2.95 perovskite as well as the segregation of Ba outside the structure [19,20]. In order to confirm the partial accomodation of Ba2+ in the perovskite structure, Fig. 2 shows an enlargement of the main diffraction peak for LaCoO3, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3, La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskites. As can be observed, the main diffraction peaks widens with increasing Ba contents. Furthermore, the crystal system varies from rhombohedral LaCoO3 perovskite (PDF number: 048–0123) to cubic La0.5Ba0.5CoO3 perovskite (PDF number: 032–0480) [21,22]. These results demonstrate that Ba2+ has been partially accommodated inside the perovskite structure leading to a modification and an enlargement of the crystalline structure. In agreement with this the main peak position (∼33.3°2θ) progressively shifts to lower 2θ values (Fig. S1). These variations are expected since the larger Ba2+ replaces smaller La3+ in the perovskite structure, which leads to increased volume of the cell and decreased crystallinity [23]. As a result, the crystal size quantified by Scherrer’s equation decreases from 58 nm, for the non-substituted LaCoO3 sample, to 16 nm for La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 catalyst (Table 1 ). Similar trend can be observed for reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite (18 nm). However, the crystal size of Sr-doped perovskite is slightly lower than in the Ba-doped counterpart (La0.7Ba0.3CoO3, 21 nm). This fact is in line with the lower accommodation degree of Ba2+ inside the perovskite structure. Indeed, the peak position of the samples with lanthanum substitution by barium above 30 % is the same (Fig. S1). This fact suggests that the perovskite structure is not further modified. The influence of Ba doping on textural properties was studied by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments at –196 °C (Table 1). The specific surface areas (SSA) clearly indicate noticeable dependence on the degree of Ba substitution. The SSA increases from 12.6 m2 g−1 for non-substituted sample to 18.7 m2 g−1 for La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 sample, then further Ba substitution decreases SSA progressively. The increase of SSA for low Ba contents, is inversely proportional to the decrease of the crystal size quantified by Scherrer’s equation (Table 1). Meanwhile, the progressive segregation of BaCO3 and BaCoO2.95, penalized the SSA for higher Ba substitution degree. It is worth noting that Sr doping shows slightly higher promotion effect on textural properties than Ba doping. In fact, the SSA ranges from 21.6 m2  g−1 for La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite to 18.7 m2  g−1 for La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 sample. Furthermore, the later shows higher crystal size. This trend is due to the higher ability of LaCoO3 to accommodate Sr in the lattice than Ba. Hydrogen consumption profiles of the La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites (Fig. 3 ) were determined by Temperature Programmed Reduction experiments (H2–TPR). As a general trend, samples with low barium content (x < 0.2) show similar reduction profile to LaCoO3 perovskite. On these perovskites, the H2 consumption at lower temperatures is ascribed to the reduction chemisorbed oxygen on oxygen vacancies and the progressive reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ from the surface to the inner layers (Eq. 8), maintaining the perovskite structure [7,12,24–26]. Meanwhile, the hydrogen consumption at higher temperatures is assigned to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0, also beginning from the surface and progressing to the bulk layers (Eq. 9). The reduction profile is significantly altered for higher doping levels (La0.8Ba0.2CoO3, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3, La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 and La0.5Ba0.5CoO3). On the one hand, hydrogen consumptions related to the reduction of cobalt shift to lower temperatures. This fact is a consequence of the higher specific surface areas and lower crystallinities derived from La3+ partial substitution by Ba2+. On the other hand, new contributions appears in the reduction profile. In agreement with the observed by XRD analysis, the additional hydrogen consumptions at low temperature can be ascribed to BaCoO2.95 perovskite reduction. This process takes place at the same temperature range than the reduction of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskite [27,28]. Meanwhile, the new contribution observed above 700 °C is assigned to surface decomposition of residual carbonates in the form of CO2, which alters the TCD signal [27]. (8) L a 1-x B a x Co O 3 + 1/2 H 2 → L a 1 - x B a x Co O 3 + 1/2 H 2 O (9) L a 1 - x B a x Co O 2.5 + H 2 → 1 − x 2 L a 2 O 3 + x BaO + C o 0 + H 2 O The H2 consumption profiles were integrated in order to calculate H2/Co ratios (Table 2 ). LaCoO3 and La0.9Ba0.1CoO3 perovskites show H2/Co ratios close to the theoretical value of 1.5 (Eqs. 8 and 9) and the hydrogen consumption assigned to the reduction of Co3+→Co2+ is half of that consumed for the reduction of Co2+→Co0. This suggests that all the cobalt in the sample was in the form of Co3+ ions. Hence, this fact suggests that the generation of oxygen vacancies is the only mechanism available to accomplish charge compensation in LaCoO3 perovskites. Indeed, the hydrogen consumption assigned to reduction of chemisorbed oxygen in surface vacancies increases with increasing barium contents. However, Ba doping above 10 % present lower Co3+/Co ratios, which can be explained by the simultaneous reduction of BaCoO2.95 and LaCoO3 perovskites, as well as Co3O4 spinel. These results suggest again the incomplete accommodation of Ba ions inside the perovskite structure due to the limited stability of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites. As observed in Fig. S2, this fact favours the reducibility of La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites with respect to La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskites [29]. Fig. 4 shows the oxygen desorption profiles (O2–TPD) for La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites. Two main desorption peaks related to different species were identified. The low temperature peak (< 550 °C) was defined as α–oxygen, whereas the high temperature desorption peak as β–oxygen (> 550 °C) [30]. α–Oxygen is assigned to desorption of weakly adsorbed species at the surface oxygen vacancies or at the dislocations and grain frontiers very near to or on the surface [21,31]. Meanwhile, β–oxygen corresponds to the oxygen desorbed from inner layers of the lattice, leading to the partial reduction of Co3+ [31]. The decomposition of surface carbonates in form of CO2 has been also observed by mass spectroscopy at this temperature region. Regarding La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite, similar oxygen desorption profile can be identified in Fig. S3. After the intregation of the O2–TPD profile the evolution of different oxygen species (Oα, Oβ and OTOTAL) with lanthanum substitution degree was obtained (Fig. 5 ). As already observed by H2–TPR experiments, barium doping does not induce any change in the cobalt oxidation state, and thus, the positive charge defect due to the substitution of La3+ by Ba2+ should be balanced by the formation of oxygen vacancies [32–36]. Indeed, the La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 variant nearly doubles the amount of Oα species with respect to the non-substituted sample. However, higher lanthanum substitution degrees penalize the amount of Oα as a consequence of the progressive formation of segregations, which reduce the specific surface area and cover oxygen vacancies at the surface. Regarding Oβ, La substitution by Ba enhances the formation of these species in the whole range, especially for lanthanum substitution degrees above 20 %. Note that a 10 % of La3+ substitution by Ba2+ was considered as the upper limit that can be accommodated in the lattice without the formation of impurities in Fig. 1. Thus, the increase of Oβ concentracion is mainly due to CO2 release by surface carbonates decomposition. Finally, it is worth to mention that the concentration of the different desorbed oxygen species is lower than in La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite, especially in the case of Oα. Specifically, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 variant desorbs 398.1 μmol O gcat −1, whereas La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 variant desorbs 695.7 μmol O gcat −1. These results suggest that the generation of surface oxygen vacancies in La1-xBaxCoO3 formulations is partially limited due to the barium lower accommodation degree in the perovskite lattice. The surface basicity of the LaCoO3, La0.3Ba0.7CoO3 and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 samples was analyzed by CO2–TPD experiments (Fig. 6 ). All samples show different basic sites classified as weak (below 200 °C), medium (200–550 °C) and strong basic sites (above 550 °C). Low temperature peaks are due to the decomposition of monodentate carbonates linked to the oxygen vacancies and structural Co at the perovskite surface. Medium basic sites are assigned to the decomposition of monodentate carbonates linked to structural La at the perovskite surface. Meanwhile, strong basic sites are assigned to the decomposition of monodenate carbonates linked to La2O3, BaCO3 or SrCO3 phases in form of surface segregations. The desorption at high temperature begins with the decomposition of adsorbed species on highly dispersed segregations followed by decomposition of CO2 adsorbed over bulk-like species with low interaction with the perovskite [37,38]. It is worth nothing that the peak assigned to desorption of strong basic sites shifts to higher temperatures for La0.3Ba0.7CoO3 perovskite. This trend is assigned to the limited Ba accomodation inside the perovskite structure, in line with the observed for La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites by XRD analysis (Fig. 1), which promotes the formation of highly stable bulk-like species at the surface [21]. Table 3 summarizes the concentration of the different species obtained after the integration of the desorption peaks observed in Fig. 6. Generally speaking, strontium and barium doping increase the surface basicity. In the case of Ba-doped sample, the surface basicity increases from 157.9 μmol CO2 g−1 for LaCoO3 perovskite to 491.2 μmol CO2 g−1 for La0.3Ba0.7CoO3 sample. Analyzing the effect of doping agent nature (Ba2+ or Sr2+), La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite shows the highest surface basicity, 553.6 μmol CO2 g−1. Based on the results obtained by XRD (Figs. 1 and 2) and N2 adsorption-desorption experiments (Table 1), Sr doping seems to promote a more homogeneous distribution and accesibility of the strong basic sites than Ba doping. However, the strength of strong basic sites is higher for La0.7Ba0.3CoO3. The presence of higher concentration of bulk-like BaCO3, as well as the higher intrinsic basicity of Ba2+ than Sr2+ favours the CO2 desorption at higher temperatures. These results suggest that the surface basicity of the catalyst is significantly influenced by the alkaline earth metal nature. 3.2 NO-to-NO2 oxidation and NOx storage and reduction activity 3.2.1 NO oxidation capacity Fig. 7 shows the evolution with temperature of the NO-to-NO2 conversion ( X NO-to-NO 2 , Eq. 1) for La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites, as well as for reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 sample. The equilibrium conversion for the studied gas stream-feed composition (500 ppm NO, 6% O2 and Ar to balance) with temperature is also included in broken line. All samples show similar evolution of NO oxidation capacity with temperature. Firstly, NO conversion increases due to the promotion of oxidation kinetic constant with temperature up to 300–350 °C. Then, NO conversion decreases in a thermodynamically controlled regime due to the exothermicity of the reaction, as shows Eq. 10 [39]. (10) NO ( g ) + 1 / 2 O 2 ⇄ N O 2 ( g ) Δ H 0 = − 57.2 kJ mo l -1 As a general trend, Ba-doped samples show higher X NO - to - NO 2 than non-substituted sample, especially at intermediate temperatures. Among prepared samples, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3 and La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskites presented the best NO-to-NO2 performance (maximum of 66 % at 350 °C). This value represents a significant improvement of NO oxidation capacity with respect LaCoO3 variant (maximum of 57 %). As described in the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, an increase in Oα concentration implies higher oxygen mobility and exchange capacity between oxygen in the lattice and in the gas phase [39–41]. As a result, this fact increases the amount of active oxygen for NO oxidation. Thus, the higher NO-to-NO2 conversion of La0.8Ba0.2CoO3 and La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskites is assigned to their higher α oxygen species concentration (O2–TPD) and accesibility (higher SSA). Meanwhile, the increase in the amount of segregations for La3+ substitutions by Ba2+ above the 30 % limits NO oxidation capacity due to decreased SSA and oxygen vacancies accesibility. In agreement with this explanation, La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite shows higher NO-to-NO2 oxidation efficiency than La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites. 3.2.2 NOx storage and reduction (NSR) efficiency Regarding NSR behaviour, Fig. 8 shows the evolution of the outlet concentrations of NO, NO2, NOx, NH3, and N2O during two consecutive lean-rich cycles. The measurements were taken at 350 °C once steady state had been achieved for LaCoO3 perovskite (Fig. 8a), La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 (Fig. 8b) and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 (Fig. 8c) samples, respectively. Note that the Sr- and Ba-doped samples included showed the best NO-to-NO2 conversion in Fig. 7. The lowest NO, NO2 and NOx outlet concentrations were observed at the beginning of the lean cycle. This is ascribed to NOx adsorption on the perovskite via two main mechanisms: i) NO2 adsorption over the basic storage components, either structural strontium or lanthanum at the perovskite surface or highly dispersed SrO or BaO and La2O3 segregarions at the surface [42], after which a disproportionation reaction generates nitrate and facilitates the release of NO [40,43], and ii) NO2 adsorption over oxygen vacancies on the surface of the perovskite. As the lean period progresses, the NOx storage sites became progressively saturated. In the case of the LaCoO3 perovskite, the NOx outlet concentration increases gradually until it matches the inlet concentration of 500 ppm NO due to the complete saturation of the NOx adsorption sites. Among doped samples, Ba-doped formulation shows the lowest NOx outlet concentration at the end of lean period, which represents a higher NOx storage capacity (NSC, Table S1). In the subsequent rich period, oxygen is replaced with a 3% of hydrogen, which reacts with the stored NOx, generating NH3, N2O and N2 as main products. Regarding the ammonia outlet concentration, it is maximum for La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 sample (around 1000 ppm); meanwhile, the N2O concentration is sligthly lower for LaCoO3 perovskite. However, it is worth nothing that a fraction of stored NOx is released without being converted. Indeed, NOx desorption peaks during rich period reach around 3000 ppm for La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 samples, and 1500 ppm for LaCoO3 perovskite. Among them, Ba-doped perovskite (La0.7Ba0.3CoO3) seems to favour a slower NOx desorption during the rich period which enhances NOx reduction ( X N O x R , Table S1). Note that the NOx desorption peak during the rich period is delayed and lower with respect to LaCoO3 and La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskites. Fig. 9 shows the evolution of NOx storage capacity (NSC, Eq. 2), NOx conversion ( X NO x , Eq. 3) and nitrogen production ( Y N 2 , Eq. 7) with reaction temperature for the different Ba-doped perovskites. These parameters were estimated using data from similar NOx storage and reduction experiments to the reported in Fig. 8. Regarding NOx storage capacity (Fig. 9a), similar patterns can be identified. Firtsly, NSC is enhanced by reaction temperature up to 350 °C, in line with the typical behaviour of BaO basic NOx storage component [2,3,43–45]. Above 350 °C, the progressive migration of Ba-based components towards catalytic surface favors the presence of additional NOx adsorption sites. This fact balances the decrease of the nitrates stability for the highly substituted samples [40,46,47]. As a consequence, the samples with barium doping at proportions higher than 10 % show their maximum NSC at 450 °C. Focusing on the effect of La3+ partial substitution by Ba2+, Ba-doping improves NSC, showing the La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 variant the best NSC in the whole temperature range. Meanwhile, barium doping at proportions higher than 30 %, did not further enhanced the NSC. Ueda et al. [48] found similar trend for Ba-doped La0.7Ba0.3Fe0.97Pd0.03O3 perovskites. The enhancement of the NSC was assigned to the presence of BaO which can act as NOx adsoprtion site. Thus, the better NSC of this formulation is probably due to a higher NO-to-NO2 conversion rate and exposed surface area, as well as oxygen vacancy and NOx adsorption sites concentrations at the surface. Fig. 9b plots NOx conversion versus reaction temperature. X NOx increases with reaction temperature proportionally to NSC up to 350 °C. However, the promotion of X NOx above 350 °C is limited due to the release of a remarkable fraction of NOx stored during the rich period without being converted, as observed in Fig. 8. This trend denotes that NOx reduction becomes as the rate limiting step at this temperature range. Among the La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites, the samples with La3+ substitution by Ba2+ above the 20 % show the highest NOx conversion values (around 40 % at 350 °C). This fact is ascribed to the presence of increasing concentrations of highly stable BaO at the surface. In agreement with the observed in Figs. 6 and 8, the stronger basicity of this phase slows down the decomposition rate of the NOx adsorbed species during the rich period, which favours their reduction with hydrogen during the short rich period (Table S1). Finally, the NOx should be efficiently reduced to N2. In this sense, Fig. 9c shows the evolution of nitrogen production with temperature. Maximum Y N 2 of around 35–40 % at 300–350 °C were observed for La1-xBaxCoO3 perovskites when lanthanum substitution degree is above 20 % (Fig. 9c). Among developed formulations La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskite shows the best yield to N2. These results confirm the good correlation between NSC, X NO x and Y N 2 values. However, the nitrogen production is lower than the amount converted above 350 °C. As reported for La1-xSrxCoO3 perovskites [7], the production of ammonia is favoured instead of nitrogen production at this temperature range (Table S1). Similar trend can be identified for N2O production in Fig. 10 b. As a result, the nitrogen production decreases due to the promotion of the selectivity towards NH3 and/or N2O above 350 °C. Regarding the effect of doping agent nature (Sr2+ or Ba2+) on NOx removal efficciency, the maximum nitrogen production of Ba-doped samples is significantly above than that shown by reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 sample, maximum of around 10 % at 350 °C. The higher NOx-to-N2 reduction efficiency is mainly ascribed to the slower nitrates decomposition during rich period. On the one hand, this fact favour the NOx reduction to N2, N2O or NH3 during rich period. On the other hand, the reduction of the nitrates stored downstream with the NH3 formed upstream is also promoted. This leads to the selective formation of N2 following the Eq. 12. Thus, Ba-doped samples can be considered as a most promising base materials for NOx emissions control in automotive applications. (11) Ba N O 3 2 + 8 H 2 ( gas ) → BaO + 2N H 3 gas + 5 H 2 O (12) Ba N O 3 2 + 8 H 2 ( gas ) → BaO + 2N H 3 gas + 5 H 2 O 4 Conclusions The partial substitution of La3+ by Ba2+ emerges as a simple way to improve the NOx removal efficiency of LaCoO3 perovskites. In particular, Ba-doped perovskites further improved NO-to-NO2 conversion and NOx storage and reduction performance compared to the non-substituted formulation (LaCoO3). The best catalytic performance was obtained with La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 formulation. The higher oxygen mobility and exchange capacity between oxygen in the lattice and gas phase oxygen was considered as the key factor to maximize the NO oxidation capacity. This fact was associated to the higher formation of oxygen vacancies to accomplish charge imbalance. Specifically, the NO oxidation capacity at 350 °C (67 %) is significantly better than that of bare LaCoO3 perovskite (57 %). Meanwhile, higher NOx storage and reduction capacity is thought to be related to the combined effect of higher NO-to-NO2 efficiency and NOx adsorption sites concentration at the surface in form of segregated BaO or structural Ba. Some differences were identified in the catalytic behaviour of the optimum Co-based perovskites (Ba-doped and Sr-doped samples). Regarding NO-to-NO2 conversion, the optimum Sr-doped sample (La0.7Sr0.3CoO3) improves the activity of La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskite. This behaviour is ascribed to the easier alkaline earth metal accommodation within the lattice by Sr doping instead of Ba doping. As a result, this fact leads to a promotion of the concentration and accessibility of the active sites for NO oxidation reaction. On the other hand, the presence of stronger basic sites in Ba-doped sample promotes a slower NOx desorption during rich period, which favours the selective reduction of NOx to N2. As a result, Ba-doped perovskite improve the NOx storage and reduction efficiency with respect to reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 perovskite. Thus, Ba-based formulations can be considered as the most promising perovskite base catalysts for automotive applications in diesel engines. In fact, these samples show NO-to-NO2 conversion and NOx storage capacities similar or even higher than NSR model catalyst (Pt-Ba/Al2O3) with a significant decrease of the cost of the catalytic system. Future efforts must be focus on improving NOx reduction efficiency of developed formulation. CRediT authorship contribution statement Jon A. coredata.dc:description: Perovskites (ABO3) have emerged in recent years as an economic alternative to noble metals for oxidation-reduction reactions in diesel engines aftertreatment systems. Sr-doped La1-xSrxCoO3 perovskites have shown high efficiency in NO oxidation and limited NOx reduction efficiency. Alternatively, in this work, the effects of barium doping on NOx removal efficiency of LaCoO3 perovskite are explored with the aim of developing a more promising perovskite base catalyst. Bulk perovskites were prepared by substituting La3+ with increasing Ba2+ doping levels, i.e. La0.9Ba0.1CoO3, La0.8Ba0.2CoO3, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3, La0.6Ba0.4CoO3 and La0.5Ba0.5CoO3. The prepared catalysts were characterized in terms of crystalline structures identification (XRD), specific surface area (N2 adsorption-desorption at -196 °C), reducibility and oxidation state of Co ions (H2-TPR), concentration and strength of adsorbed oxygen species (O2-TPD) and surface basicity (CO2-TPD). The characterization results suggest that charge imbalance associated to Ba2+ accommodation in the perovskite lattice in substitution of La3+ leads to a preferential formation of oxygen vacancies. As a result, Ba-doped perovskites improve NO-to-NO2 conversion with respect to LaCoO3 perovskite. La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 perovskite shows the best NO oxidation efficiency (66 % at 350 °C). This fact is associated to the higher oxygen vacancies concentration, which favors the exchange capacity between oxygen in the lattice and in the gas phase. This sample also shows the best NOx storage and reduction efficiency (maximum NOx-to-N2 reduction of 40 % at 350 °C). On the one hand, NOx adsorption is promoted due to the best balance between NO oxidation capacity and NOx adsorption sites accessibility. On the other hand, the higher strength of NOx adsorption sites promotes a slower nitrates decomposition, which favors NOx reduction during rich period. The obtained results improve the NOx removal efficiency of reference La0.7Sr0.3CoO3 sample (maximum NOx-to-N2 reduction of 10 % at 350 °C). Thus, La0.7Ba0.3CoO3 catalyst is considered as a more promising base material for automotive applications.
coredata.dc:title: Ba-doped vs. Sr-doped LaCoO3 perovskites as base catalyst in diesel exhaust purification
